text.result:
The fastest animal on land is the cheetah. This remarkable creature can reach speeds of up to 60-70 miles per hour (97-113 kilometers per hour) over short distances, reaching its top speed within about 3 seconds. Cheetahs have several adaptations that contribute to their incredible speed, such as a lean body, long legs, and a unique, flexible spine that acts like a spring for burst of energy during a chase.

For marine animals, the title goes to the Sailfish. This magnificent fish is capable of reaching impressive speeds, up to 68 miles per hour (110 kilometers per hour), as it uses its long sail-like dorsal fin for propulsion and maneuvering during hunting.

It's important to note that these are remarkable examples of speed in the animal kingdom, but there may be other creatures with even higher top-end speeds, especially those that have not yet been extensively studied or documented.

text.result:
In Europe, the fastest land animal is still the cheetah, as it does not inhabit this continent naturally due to its preference for open savannas and grasslands. However, if we consider European land mammals with significant speed, the Greater Kudu (Tragelaphus stoical) comes close. This antelope can reach impressive speeds of up to 58 km/h (36 mph), although not as fast as cheetahs.

Among marine animals in European waters, the Swordfish (Xiphias gladius) holds the crown for being the fastest. It can swim at speeds of up to 70-115 km/h (43-72 mph), making it one of the most powerful fish and the fastest among all saltwater fish species.

Keep in mind that there might be other, lesser-known or more specialized European animals with remarkable speed, but these two examples are often highlighted due to their impressive capabilities within their respective environments.
